Award.AwardTitle: Shimura varieties, Galois modules and Galois representations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI is attempting to describe integral models for Shimura varieties at primes of non-smooth reduction and study related p-adic spaces. In particular, he investigates the structure of the singularities of Shimura varieties at such primes using methods from the theory of algebraic loop groups and p-adic Hodge theory and he is developing a theory of ``local models" for these varieties. The motivation is to obtain information that can be used in the calculation of their Hasse-Weil zeta functions and in other number theoretic applications. He is also studying closely connected p-adic spaces such as deformation spaces of local Galois representations, Rapoport-Zink spaces and their p-adic cohomology. In addition he is studying the representations that appear in the cohomology of arithmetic varieties with a finite group action and is developing related Riemann-Roch type theorems. In the past, the PI has obtained formulae useful for calculating equivariant Euler characteristics of varieties over the integers with an abelian group action. He is extending his work to the case of non-abelian group actions and he will apply his techniques to deduce information about Galois modules obtained from covers of modular curves. He is also developing refined versions of Riemann-Roch type theorems that allow for calculations of torsion classes, and, in some cases, he is providing local or adelic descriptions of the isomorphisms underlying the Riemann-Roch identities.

This is research in the field of arithmetic algebraic geometry,a subject that blends two of the oldest areas of mathematics: the geometry of shapes that can be described by the simplest equations, namely polynomials, and the study of numbers. This combination of disciplines has proved extraordinarily fruitful - having solved problems that withstood generations (such as ``Fermat's last theorem"). The proposal mainly concentrates on the study of specific polynomial equations that have many symmetries. The general field has connections with physics, the construction of error correcting codes and cryptography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research work supported by this grant is in a part of mathematics called "arithmetic algebraic geometry''. This lies in the intersection of number theory and algebraic geometry.

Number theory is the ancient study of properties of whole numbers with questions such as Fermat's problem: The equation x^n+y^n=z^n, for n bigger than two, has no solutions in integers (except the obvious ones, where one of x, y, z is zero). Algebraic geometry is the study of the properties of systems of polynomial equations in many variables and of their solution sets in real or complex numbers. (For example, x^n+y^n=z^n is such a polynomial equation. The points with coordinates (x, y, z), with x, y, z real numbers and x^n+y^n=z^n, is a conical surface in space.) In the terminology of this field, these solution sets are called "varieties''. The field has important applications in cryptography, the construction and study of codes.

 Recently, the two subjects of number theory and algebraic geometry have been interacting in a profound way. An additional ingredient in this interaction is the study of symmetries of polynomial equations. A collection of all possible symmetries is a mathematical object called a  "group'' (or "Galois group") and symmetries can be studied by examining "group representations''. There is a deep conjectural relationship between such representations and corresponding algebraic geometric and number theoretic objects. The precise mechanism of this is too technical to explain here. (It is expressed as a duality, reminiscent of the duality between electricity and magnetism in physics.) Verifying this relationship is referred to as "the Langlands program''. The combination of all these powerful ideas has lead to spectacular advances: For example, Fermat's problem, and many other related questions, has now been solved.

A large part of the work supported by the grant has been on the study of "Shimura varieties''. These are solution sets of certain special systems of polynomial equations with a large group of symmetries. Understanding these varieties is important for the Langlands program. For example, it is believed that all varieties can be, somehow, obtained from Shimura varieties. The verification of this belief in a very special case led to the solution of Fermat's problem.

In my work, I have been trying to describe systems of polynomial equations that give Shimura varieties with the additional property that all the coefficients of the equations are integers. This is a requirement crucial for applications. In particular, I have been looking at situations where these varieties acquire singularities when the coefficients are reduced modulo a prime number and I have studied these singularities. This was done via the introduction of their so-called "local models'' and resulted in considerable progress in the area, including the resolution of a conjecture of R. Kottwitz.

 Another big part of my work has been the study of the group representations that occur in the homology of varieties with symmetries. In classical algebraic geometry, an important tool for understanding the homology of varieties is the Grothendieck-Riemann-Roch formula. I have spent considerable effort in developing variations and refinements of this formula. I have also introduced various new tools that allow for the calculation of these group representations.

The research supported by this grant has resulted in several publications in top peer-reviewed journals. (There is a list in the more technical part of the Final Report for the award.) It has also supported the training of Ph. D graduate students and postdoctoral researchers which increases the footprint of mathematics in society in general.
